docs.lead_paragraph: Governors and members of Congress from both parties today denounced President Clinton's proposal to impose firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending, and the governors offered a number of alternative ways to save money. At separate hearings in the Senate and the House, Mr. Clinton's proposal for annual per-capita limits on Medicaid spending won support from only one lawmaker: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a conservative Republican, who said such restraints would help balance the Federal budget.

headline.main: President's Plan to Rein In Medicaid Costs Draws Bipartisan Fire

docs.snippet: Governors and members of Congress from both parties today denounced President Clinton's proposal to impose firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending, and the governors offered a number of alternative ways to save money.    At separate hearings in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a nursing administrator became a patient in her own hospital at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, two other employees decided to indulge their curiosity by logging onto the computer system and reading her medical records. That snooping violated hospital rules, and unbeknownst to the nosy employees, their actions were being monitored. Officials at the medical center had just begun testing a new computer security system that included an ''audit trail,'' a record of each person who looked up a patient's records.
docs.abstract: Hospital computers systems can now incorporate 'audit trails' to keep employees from prying into records of patients who may be fellow hospital employees, celebrities or people with sensitive diagnoses; snooping is such a problem at hospitals that employees of one hospital have been known to seek treatment at another for fear that their privacy might be violated (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With water treatment plants throughout the Ohio River Valley overcome by floods, and raw sewage sent flowing downriver as a result, the authorities are growing concerned about the potential for disease across the waterlogged region. In several counties within the five states battered by the weeklong flooding, residents are being warned to boil their drinking water and, as they return home to clean up the muck, to care for any wounds by getting fresh diphtheria and tetanus shots.

headline.main: States Hit by Floods Turn to Threat of Disease

docs.abstract: Authorities are concerned about potential for disease in Ohio River Valley, with water treatment plants throughout waterlogged region overcome by floods and raw sewage flowing downriver as result; floods have caused death of some 35 people, left tens of thousands homeless and done hundreds of millions of dollars in damage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I object to Lloyd M. Krieger's March 8 Op-Ed article. As a recent resident physician still in training, I do not understand how shifting the financial burden of medical education from the Government to managed care and insurance companies, as he suggests, can be a panacea for problems with residency training.

headline.main: If We Don't Pay for Doctor Training, Who Will?

docs.abstract: Dr Frederick G P Welt letter opposes Dr Lloyd M Krieger March 8 Op-Ed article suggesting that financial burden of medical education should be shifted from Government to managed care and insurance companies

docs.lead_paragraph: The public is less than aghast at the campaign-finance scandal that has media and Washington people in shock. Despite the uproar, President Clinton's popularity rating stands at about 60 percent. Considering that he was re-elected by only 49 percent of the vote, it's tempting to wonder if the scandal hasn't actually been a blessing for him. This puzzles people whose days are spent pondering the news of Washington, but surely there is no mystery about it. It simply confirms what all well-informed humanity was saying just a few weeks ago; to wit, that cynicism about government has settled into the American marrow.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker Op-Ed column notes that Pres Clinton's popularity rating stands at about 60 percent despite campaign-finance scandal; contends that public respect for governing classes seems so low that we have become numb to scandal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Preserving privacy in the ever-expanding world of electronic medical records is a daunting task that health care organizations and public policy makers have been slow to address. But as managed care puts more information into more hands, consumer anxiety over confidentiality makes the issue unavoidable. While some states have enacted safeguards, there is a clear need for Federal rules that would apply to all states, particularly as more health information flows across state lines. Some recent developments may at last push Congress to act. The 1996 Kassebaum-Kennedy legislation on health insurance reform mandated a three-year timetable for Congress to act on medical confidentiality. A committee, appointed by Health and Human Services Secretary Donna Shalala, is now at work on the issue. The 1996 act also set a February 1998 deadline by which time H.H.S. must propose security standards for a ''universal health identifier'' capable of linking a patient's files anywhere in the health care system.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that preserving privacy in ever-expanding world of electronic medical records is daunting task that health care organizations and public policy makers have been slow to address; maintains that while some states have enacted safeguards, there is clear need for Federal rules that will apply to all states, particularly as more health information flows across state lines (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your March 5 Arts pages article on the art world's support for Pat Hearn, a New York gallery owner who has liver cancer, says that ''Ms. Hearn's illness is also putting a spotlight on the problem of health insurance in the art world.'' This may leave the impression that because artists are self-employed, they have difficulty getting health insurance.

headline.main: If We Don't Pay for Doctor Training, Who Will?

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress has begun a great debate on the proper role of Government in regulating health care and seems quite likely to set standards for health maintenance organizations as Democrats and Republicans scramble to outdo each other in protecting consumers. Managed-care companies denounce the prospect of new Federal regulation but find themselves in an awkward position because they also say they want to protect consumers. Employers strenuously oppose new regulation, fearing that it would hamper their ability to control the cost of employees' health benefits through managed care.

headline.main: CONGRESS WEIGHS MORE REGULATION ON MANAGED CARE

docs.abstract: Congress is expected to impose more regulation on health maintenance organizations as Democrats and Republicans vie to outdo each other in protecting consumers; managed-care companies denounce prospect of new regulation but also profess to favor consumer protection; employers strenuously oppose new regulation as an obstacle to containing cost of employees' health benefits through managed care; lawmakers, motivated less by ideology than constituent pressure, say Federal standards in field historically left to the states has become necessary with growth of managed care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are giving up their right to sue. To sue their banks over credit card and account disputes. To sue their real estate agents overdeals gone awry. To sue their mortgage companies over false advertising. To sue their doctors for malpractice or their health plans over coverage. Even to sue a computer maker over a defective machine. Often they are giving up the right without even knowing it, consenting to have disputes settled outside a courtroom through arbitration in which a private referee or panel renders a binding, nonappealable decision.

headline.main: In Fine Print, Customers Lose Ability to Sue

docs.abstract: Americans are signing away their right to sue, often without even knowing it, by consenting to have disputes with banks, doctors, retailers and others settled through arbitration in which a private referee or panel renders a binding, nonappealable decision; consumer advocates and some scholars fear that wider use of arbitration is sharply limiting the kind of compensation that individuals can receive and warn that system of private justice fostered by the trend conceals wrongdoing from the public; supporters say alternatives to litigation free up courts and provide benefits to companies and customers alike by reducing time and expense of resolving disputes, but even supporters are disturbed by how arbitration clauses are slipped into contracts in ways that escape all but the most conscientious consumer; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, the state announced new regulations governing health maintenance organizations that consumer groups called some of the strongest laws in the country. Today, legislative committees in both houses will hold a joint hearing on a bill to offer the same protections to the two million New Jersey residents who belong to other managed-care plans, such as preferred provider organizations.
